factoid: The Rostóvs went to the Opera that evening.
Márya Dmítrievna had taken a box for the opera.
Natásha did not want to go to the opera.
Natásha could not refuse Márya Dmítrievna’s kind offer.
The offer was intended expressly for Natásha.
Natásha came ready dressed into the ballroom to await her father.
Natásha looked in the large mirror and saw that she was pretty.
Natásha felt sad but the sadness was sweet and tender.
Natásha thought that if her father were here now she would behave differently.
Natásha thought that she would not be silly and afraid of things.
Natásha thought that she would embrace her father and cling to him.
Natásha thought that she would make her father look at her with searching inquiring eyes.
Natásha thought that she would make her father laugh as he used to laugh.
Natásha thought that her father's eyes were searching and inquiring.
Natásha thought that the man's father and sister did not matter to her.
Natásha thought that she should not think of the man she loves, but forget him for the present.
Natásha felt that she could not bear waiting and would cry in a minute.
Natásha turned away from the glass and made an effort not to cry.
Natásha thought about how Sónya could love Nicholas calmly and quietly and wait so long and patiently.
Natásha thought that Sónya was altogether different.
Natásha felt softened and tender.
Natásha wanted to embrace the man she loved and hear words of love from him.
Natásha sat in the carriage beside her father, pensively watching the lights of the street lamps flickering on the frozen window.
Natásha felt sadder and more in love while watching the street lamps.
Natásha forgot where she was going and with whom.
The Rostóvs carriage drove up to the theater, its wheels squeaking over the snow.
Natásha and Sónya held up their dresses and jumped out of the carriage quickly.
The count got out of the carriage helped by the footmen.
The count, Natásha, and Sónya went along the corridor to the first row of boxes.
Through the closed doors the music was already audible.
Sónya whispered 'Natásha, your hair!' to Natásha.
An attendant opened the door of Natásha and Sónya's box.
The music sounded louder through the open door.
The curtain had not yet risen and the overture was being played.
Natásha, smoothing her gown, went in with Sónya and sat down.
Natásha scanned the brilliant tiers of boxes opposite.
Natásha had not experienced the sensation of hundreds of eyes looking at her bare arms and neck.
The sensation of hundreds of eyes looking at Natásha affected her both agreeably and disagreeably and called up a whole crowd of memories, desires, and emotions.
The two remarkably pretty girls, Natásha and Sónya, and Count Rostóv, who had not been seen in Moscow for a long time, attracted general attention.
Everyone knew vaguely of Natásha’s engagement to Prince Andrew.
Everyone knew that the Rostóvs had lived in the country ever since.
All looked with curiosity at the fiancée who was making one of the best matches in Russia.
Natásha’s looks had improved in the country.
That evening, thanks to her agitation, Natásha was particularly pretty.
Natásha struck those who saw her by her fullness of life and beauty.
Natásha’s black eyes looked at the crowd without seeking anyone.
Natásha’s delicate arm, bare above the elbow, lay on the velvet edge of the box.
Natásha opened and closed her hand in time to the music, crumpling her program.
Sónya said, 'Look, there's Alénina.'
Sónya said, 'with her mother, isn’t it?'
The count remarked, 'Dear me, Michael Kirílovich has grown still stouter!'
Sónya said, 'Look at our Anna Mikháylovna—what a headdress she has on!'
Sónya said, 'The Karágins, Julie, and Borís with them. One can see at once that they’re engaged.'
Someone asked, 'Drubetskóy has proposed?'
